{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3497342,"name":"Totino-Grace Pizza Pi","username":"TotinoGracePizzaPis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a587f6/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-31T01:26:59.112Z","cooked":"

After updating our swerve code to 2025, our wheels are still oscillating around a specific setpoint. We’re watching it go from -3.14 to 3.14. They’re overshooting but never plateaus, so it keeps spiking but never fixing itself. We’ve done PID tuning by setting our turn P and D to 0.0 and increasing P over time but once P is high enough to change it oscillates again. There is no “correct” PID value.

We use Mk4i motors, CANCoders, and SparkMax controllers. Here is a link to our current code – Totino-Grace robotics control team / 2025_Robot_Code · GitLab

The image represents what the turn angles look like. The light gray/blue line (the straight one) is the expected value (or the setpoint) while the red line is the actual angle value.

If anyone has any suggestions please let us know! We cannot use the CTRE-generated code since we don’t use Talon or Kraken motors.

Screenshot 2025-01-30 1917021312×659 31.9 KB

Bad behavior can be caused by the angle encoders not reflecting the wheels. The encoders could be out of phase from the wheels for example; that is say the wheels rotated 0 to 180 but the encoder followed that but said 0 to -180 the reverse direction. Units could be wrong - radians or rotations for one device but degrees for another device.

Check that the angles are consistent and the encoders follow the physical position of the wheels (prints and plots of all the positions in time). And make sure the appropriate units conversions have been done as each library or device requires.

We’ve zeroed our CANCoders recently and they’re behaving correctly. Additionally, we’ve used the REVClient to ensure that our NEO Brushless motors are spinning the correct way when applying positive voltage. Our swerve code is the same as last year but we haven’t heard about new unit conversions.

Side note – we have an L2 gear ratio.
